# Powers Recap {.center background-color="#041E42" style="color: #d6d6d6; text-align: center;"}

## Index Laws 

Recall for $x\in\mathbb{R}$ and $n,m\in\mathbb{Z}$ we define
$$
  x^n = \underbrace{x\times x\times\cdots\times x}_{n~\text{times}},\qquad x^{-n}=\frac{1}{x^n}.
$$

Given those definitions, the **index laws** are:
$$
  x^m \times x^n = x^{m+n}, \qquad {(x^m)}^n = x^{m\times n},
$$
$$
  \frac{x^m}{x^n} = x^{m-n}, \qquad x^{0} = 1\ \text{(if $x\neq0$)}.
$$

The index laws can be used to find similar $n^{\text{th}}$ **root laws**:
$$
  x^{\frac{1}{n}} = \sqrt[n]{x}, \qquad \sqrt[n]{xy} = \sqrt[n]{x}\times\sqrt[n]{y}, \qquad \sqrt[n]{\frac{x}{y}} = \frac{\sqrt[n]{x}}{\sqrt[n]{y}}.
$$

::: {.notes}
None of this should be new, though it might be the first time you've seen it written out as a concrete set of algebraic "laws".
:::

## Polynomials

```{r}
#| label: r-setup
#| warning: false
#| message: false
#| cache: true
library(ggplot2)

base_axes <- ggplot(data.frame(x=c(-5, 5)), aes(x=x)) +
  # add axis lines to help guide plots
  geom_vline(xintercept=0, colour="grey") +
  geom_hline(yintercept=0, colour="grey")
```

These laws lets us build and work with **polynomials** of the form
$$
  y = a_nx^n + a_{n-1}x^{n-1} + \cdots + a_2x^2 + a_1x + a_0
$$
where each $a_m\in\mathbb{R}$ is a **coefficient** and each $x^{m}$ is a **power** of $x$.

What if rather than $y = x^b$, we had $y = b^x$?

::: {layout-ncol=2}
```{r}
#| label: x-squared
#| out-width: 90%
#| fig-format: svg
#| fig-alt: "Plot of y = x squared."
#| fig-cap: "Plot of $y = x^2$."
#| fig-width: 3
#| fig-height: 2
#| cache: true

base_axes + stat_function(fun=function(x){x**2}, colour="lightskyblue")
```

```{r}
#| label: two-to-the-x
#| out-width: 90%
#| fig-format: svg
#| fig-alt: "Plot of y = 2 to the power of x."
#| fig-cap: "Plot of $y = 2^x$."
#| fig-width: 3
#| fig-height: 2
#| cache: true

base_axes + stat_function(fun=function(x){2**x}, colour="darkorange")
```
:::

## Exponentials

An **exponential** equation one of the form $y = b^x$, $b\in\mathbb{R}$.

::: {layout-ncol=2}
```{r}
#| label: increase-base-comparison
#| out-width: 90%
#| fig-format: svg
#| fig-alt: "Comparison of y = a to the power of x for a = 1, 2, 3, and 4."
#| fig-cap: "Comparison of $1^x$, $2^x$, $3^x$, and $4^x$."
#| fig-width: 3
#| fig-height: 2
#| cache: true

base_axes +
  stat_function(fun=function(x){1**x}, colour="lightskyblue1") +
  stat_function(fun=function(x){2**x}, colour="lightskyblue2") +
  stat_function(fun=function(x){3**x}, colour="lightskyblue3") +
  stat_function(fun=function(x){4**x}, colour="lightskyblue4") +
  ylim(0, 100)
```

```{r}
#| label: base-reciprocal-comparison
#| out-width: 90%
#| fig-format: svg
#| fig-alt: "Comparison of y = 2 to the power of x and y = 0.5 to the power of x."
#| fig-cap: "Comparison of $y = 2^x$ and $y = 0.5^x$."
#| fig-width: 3
#| fig-height: 2
#| cache: true

base_axes +
  stat_function(fun=function(x){2**x}, colour="lightskyblue") +
  stat_function(fun=function(x){0.5**x}, colour="darkorange")
```
:::

We can still use our nice index laws:
$$
  a^xb^x = (ab)^x, \qquad b^x \times b^y = b^{x+y}, \qquad {(b^x)}^y = b^{xy}, \qquad \frac{b^x}{b^y} = b^{x-y}.
$$

::: {.notes}
When applying index laws with exponentials (and in general), do make sure you aren't confusing what is the 'base' and what is the 'power'.
:::

## Logs

The **exponential** operation $b = a^n$ has two inverses depending whether want $a$ or $n$:

- the **root** gives $a = \sqrt[n]{b}$,
- the **logarithm** gives $n = \log_{a}(b)$.

As we had **root laws**, we have equivalent **log laws**.

Index Rule                  | Log Law
:-------------------------- | :---------------------------------------
$a^m \times a^n = a^{m+n}$  | $\log_{a}(mn) = \log_a(m) + \log_a(n)$
${(a^m)}^n = a^{m\times n}$ | $\log_{a}{\left(m^n\right)} = n\times\log_{a}(m)$
$\frac{a^m}{a^n} = a^{m-n}$ | $\log_{a}{\left(\frac{m}{n}\right)} = \log_{a}(m) - \log_{a}(n)$
$a^0 = 1$                   | $\log_{a}(1) = 1$
$a^{-n} = \frac{1}{a^m}$    | $\log_{a}\left(\frac{1}{n}\right) = -\log_{a}(n)$

## Standard Base

The **standard exponential** is $y = e^x$, where $e$ is Euler's number ($e\approx2.72$).

```{r}
#| label: standard-exp-comparison
#| warning: false
#| message: false
#| out-width: 60%
#| fig-format: svg
#| fig-alt: "Plot demonstrating that the standard exponential and the natural log are inverses."
#| fig-cap: "Comparison of $y = e^x$ and $y = \\ln(x)$."
#| fig-width: 5
#| fig-height: 3
#| cache: true

base_axes +
  stat_function(fun=function(x){x}, colour="grey") +
  stat_function(fun=function(x){exp(x)}, colour="lightskyblue") +
  stat_function(fun=function(x){log(x)}, n=1e4, colour="darkorange") +
  ylim(-10,10)
```

Inverting this gives $x = \ln(y)$, where $\ln$ is the **natural log** $\log_{e}$.

# Modelling {.center background-color="#041E42" style="color: #d6d6d6; text-align: center;"}

## General Model

The **general exponential model** has the form is
$$
  y = a\times e^{b(x-c)} + d.
$$

Here $x$ and $y$ are variables, while $a,b,c,d\in\mathbb{R}$ are parameters to tune.

```{r}
#| label: geogebra_exponential
#| fig-alt: "Interactive applet in GeoGebra, looking at the general exponential model."
#| dev: "png"
#| cache: true
knitr::include_url("https://www.geogebra.org/material/iframe/id/xdehvxe5/width/1800/height/800/sri/true/sdz/true")
```

::: {.notes}
- $a$ controls **vertical stretch** by a factor of $a$,
- $b$ controls **horizontal stretch** by a factor of $\frac{1}{b}$,
- $c$ controls **horizontal translation** by $c$ units,
- $d$ controls **vertical translation** by $d$ units.
:::

## Logistic Model

Building on this is the **logistic model**, which has the form is
$$
  y = \frac{1}{1 + e^{-(a+bx)}}.
$$

Here $x$ and $y$ are variables, while $a,b\in\mathbb{R}$ are parameters to tune.[^simplified]

```{r}
#| label: geogebra_logistic
#| fig-alt: "Interactive applet in GeoGebra, looking at the logistic model."
#| dev: "png"
#| cache: true
knitr::include_url("https://www.geogebra.org/material/iframe/id/kvvgr3xy/width/1800/height/600/sri/true/sdz/true")
```

[^simplified]: This is a slightly simplified model, but still has uses!

This is not essential content, and can be briefly skipped over or explored in detail as time allows!

## Moore's Law

> Complexity for minimum component costs has increased at a rate of roughly a factor of two per year. Certainly over the short term this rate can be expected to continue.[^Moore]

If we start with 1 and then repeatedly double, it will follow the trend

```{r}
#| label: powers-of-two
2**(0:12)
```

and at the $n^{\text{th}}$ step we will have $2^n$. Moore's law can be modelled as

$$
  B(T) = 2^\frac{T - 1949}{2},
$$

where computing power $B$ in bits is a function of $T$ the current year.

[^Moore]: Moore, Gordon E. (April 19, 1965). _"Cramming more components onto integrated circuits"_, Electronics Magazine.

:::{.notes}
In 1965, engineer Gordon Moore noticed that the number of transistors it was possible to put on a computer circuit board was increasing roughly every two years (Moore, 1965).
:::

## oh no

What's the problem when we plot this?

```{r}
#| label: moores-law-exponential=
#| out-width: 70%
#| fig-format: svg
#| fig-alt: "Plot of Moore's Law as a function on Cartesian axes."
#| fig-cap: "Plot of Moore's Law, $B(T) = 2^{\\frac{T-1949}{2}}$."
#| fig-width: 5
#| fig-height: 3
#| cache: true

moores_plot <-ggplot(data.frame(x=c(1970, 2020)), aes(x=x)) +
  geom_hline(yintercept=0, colour="grey") +
  stat_function(fun=function(x){2**((x-1949)/2)}, col="lightskyblue")

moores_plot + labs(x="T (year)", y="B (computing power in bits)")
```

## log axes

To keep interpretability, we transform the plot!

```{r}
#| label: moores-law-log
#| warnings: false
#| messages: false
#| out-width: 80%
#| fig-format: svg
#| fig-alt: "Plot of Moore's Law as a function on log-linear axes."
#| fig-cap: "Plot of Moore's Law, $B(T) = 2^{\\frac{T-1949}{2}}$, on log-linear axes."
#| fig-width: 5
#| fig-height: 3
#| cache: true

library(scales)

moores_plot + scale_y_continuous(
  trans='log2',
  breaks=trans_breaks('log2', function(x) 2^x),
  labels=trans_format('log2', math_format(2^.x))
) + labs(x="T (year)", y="log2(B) (power in log bits base 2)")
```
